Coordinate Functions

Source: vignettes/Coordinate Functions.Rmd
Coordinate Functions.Rmd

Here we will be covering the functions to transform between coordinate representations. We will start with the representation a <- c(-10,0,10) of a longitude or latitude.

library(NcLibrary)

a <- c(-10,0,10)
lat_to_str(a)
#> [1] "10S" "0N"  "10N"
lon_to_str(a)
#> [1] "10W" "0E"  "10E"

Note that as default the 0 is given one of the coordinates. But 0W is equivalent to 0E and equally with the latitude. Now we will see how to do the reverse change.


lon <- c("10W","0W","0E","10E")
lat <- c("10S","0S","0N","10N")

str_to_lon(lon)
#> [1] -10   0   0  10
str_to_lat(lat)
#> [1] -10   0   0  10

The functions return error if it is not a good string representation.


lon <- c("10N") # Wrong longitude
lat <- c("10N") # Wrong latitude

tryCatch({str_to_lon(lon)},error=function(e) print(e))
#> <simpleError in FUN(X[[i]], ...): Invalid longitude format. Use 'E' or 'W' at the end of the string.>

tryCatch({str_to_lat(lat)},error=function(e) print(e))
#> [1] 10

Finally there is a function to check if a coordinate is inside a grid given by the two arrays of latitude and longitude:


lon <- c(1,2,3,4,5)
lat <- c(4,5,6,7,8)

coord_is_inside(c(5,5), lon, lat) #Inside
#> [1] TRUE
coord_is_inside(c(3,3), lon, lat) #Not inside 
#> [1] FALSE
